message_1: Find the interval of convergence of the power series $\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty}\dfrac{z^{n}}{n^{2}}$.
message_2:
To find the interval of convergence of the power series $\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty}\dfrac{z^{n}}{n^{2}}$, we will use the Ratio Test. The Ratio Test states that if $\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| < 1$, then the series converges, and if the limit is greater than 1, the series diverges. If the limit equals 1, the test is inconclusive.

In this case, the general term of the series is $a_n = \dfrac{z^n}{n^2}$. Applying the Ratio Test, we have:

$\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| = \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{\dfrac{z^{n+1}}{(n+1)^2}}{\dfrac{z^n}{n^2}}\right| = \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{z^{n+1}n^2}{z^n(n+1)^2}\right|$

Simplifying the expression, we get:

$\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{z\cdot n^2}{(n+1)^2}\right| = |z|\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{n^2}{(n+1)^2}\right|$

Since the limit of the ratio of the powers of n is 1, we have:

$|z|\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\dfrac{n^2}{(n+1)^2}\right| = |z|$

For the series to converge, we need the limit to be less than 1:

$|z| < 1$

This inequality represents the interval of convergence for the power series:

$-1 < z < 1$

So, the interval of convergence of the power series $\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty}\dfrac{z^{n}}{n^{2}}$ is $(-1, 1)$.
